reviewText:
Karan (Akshaye Khanna) and Priya (Amisha Patel) are the lead pair of a dance troupe & in love with each other. They land a gig on a cruise ship (destined for Malaysia) owned by a rich businessman named Raj (Bobby Deol). Raj, who is attracted to Priya at first sight, doesn't know that Priya and Karan are in love. Raj quickly falls for Priya and she is totally swept off her feet. While Karan is unaware, Raj continues to romance and woo Priya. Eventually Raj proposes to Priya and she eagerly agrees to marry him.

The story takes a twist when we find out that Priya and Karan have been scheming and plotting all along to take Raj's money. So begins a treacherous love triangle, where greed, ambition and love cause turmoil in their lives. So they plan to get a divorce from Raj and become millionaires with the share Priya gets from divorce. But Raj loves Priya very dearly. Priya goes to Karan for the next plan for divorce. Karan instructs her not to be stressed. He would manage the divorce papers. She just needs to say that Raj never consummated the marriage because he is impotent. Meanwhile another dancer from the troupe gets a wind of their plot & starts blackmailing Karan. Karan meets him at designated place to hand him over the money, but instead kills him. Unknown to Karan just before dying he calls Raj to reveal the truth. Since Raj is not in his office the call goes in the voice mailbox.

Worried with the dilemma of choosing caring husband over personal ambition, Priya meets with an accident while returning home. Raj showers Priya with all his love and care. Priya is overwhelmed to know Raj has kept a prayer for Priya's fast recovery and had kept a fast since 2 days. Priya decides to reveal the truth to Raj and hence tells Karan that she will not go through with the divorce. Karan feels betrayed and decides to get his revenge on Priya and Raj. He feigns a call from his troupe member & acts as if he is been harassed for bribe. Priya decides to give her jewellery to Karan in order to save him. However Karan calls Raj from public phone with voice over & lies to him that Priya loves Karan & she giving away money looted from Raj's to Karan. Raj follows her & sees that Priya meeting Karan & handing over her jewelery. Raj misunderstands and plots to punish her.

As per the plan, Raj has paid Karan to kill Priya and make it look like a robbery. Raj explains each and every point of the plan right upto precise time & doors to be used for murder & says that he will call on the landline as he wants to hear Priya scream while she is dying.

Priya unbeknownst, decides to confess everything to Raj in an audio recording and replace the tape with the music cassette in Raj's car. She knows that Raj has habit of hearing music while traveling to office. In the recordings she mentions that if Raj has forgiven her, he should give a call. If not she will leave him forever.

As luck would have it, Raj is traveling with an employee that day and hence doesn't listen to the tape. Karan enters the house as planned and waits for the call. At the same time Priya is also waiting for the call from Raj expecting him to forgive her. Raj calls the landline as planned, an excited Priya answers the phone. Karan attacks her at the same time and ensures Raj is able to hear her screams. Raj listens to the tape as he sits in the car in horror. He rushes to save Priya only to see the police and an ambulance waiting at the house.

It is revealed that Priya is saved and the savior is none other than Karan, meanwhile a small time thug is dead. He then blackmails Raj saying he had recorded the meeting with him about the murder and to avoid any complications demands that Raj divorce Priya with large alimony as a part of his ransom plan. Karan reaches Raj's ancestral house and tries to blackmail Raj by pressuring him about the consequence to his extended family members if they find Raj is jailed for planning Priya's murder. Raj goes to meet Karan at a decided spot where he says he is ready to go to jail, but will not give any money to Karan. Both men break out in a fight, but stop when Priya arrives. Karan tells her about Raj's plan to kill her, but Priya says she is aware of it and knew Karan was blackmailing Raj. In the End Priya Kills Karan & reunites with Raj.

Personally have always enjoyed the director duo's filmmaking style, and they don't disappoint this time either.
This title might have not been a commercial blockbuster however it is an excellent work.
The direction is outstanding as one would expect from this duo, casting was just perfect specially that of Bobby Deol playing the wealthy millionaire.
Bobby Deol has proven himself once again that he is very much a capable actor with range.  His new look, customs, dialogues, everything about him just works.  His performance is fluid and effortless.  The script has given his character so many shades and he does not fail portraying them on the big  screen.
The music has a few pleasant tracks except when the dance groups starts performing! Found it to be a bit silly and unnecessary.
It is a movie that you can watch over and still enjoy every frame.
An excellent work.

When I was surfing trying to get an idea of this movie, the emphasis was on entertaining romance with Hitchcock twists and turns. The cover has a sinister set of stills and talks of man's dark side.
I don't like violent Indian movies and I wasn't sure whether this was for me.
Actually it was violence on a par with Hollywood action movies like Indiana Jones or Mission Impossible. They did have an extended fight scene at the end (when the resolution of the movie was very much in doubt quite a few times) but it was no more gratuitous in images than something like Spiderman.
What is very much to recommend about this movie is that the plot is well devised and there are many satisfying surprise twists in the last half.
The first half is focused more on setting a romantic web and has light musical numbers. Booby Deol plays a charismatic lover who is worth watching just for that (I'm not sure why he has concentrated on more action and violent flicks as he can express love and sensitivity so well when he chooses). The female lead is good (but I'm a female and may appreciate her acting rather than her charms!) The baddy (Akshaye Khanna)is stereotypically a cad and does that with believable finesse.
As with so many Indian movies the first and second halves contrast in their mood. The first half is light, romantic and full of music, romance and beautiful settings. The second half is well crafted thriller.
I found the violence when it did happen wasn't too sustained generally and was more action sequence stuff- and was endurable for those who don't like violent movies but manage occasional action.

Corny lead-in, yes, but then this whole crazy, over the top, wildly exotic, incredibly colorful hoopla takeoff on Hollywood musicals and thrillers is so 'too much' that it is an utter delight!  Some might think that the term 'Bollywood' is an affront to Hindi cinema, but it would seem from the extended trailers and PR before the opening of this movie that the Indians are the ones who created and luxuriate in the term.  At any rate HUMRAAZ is a spectacle and well worth the 173 minutes it takes to watch it.

The story seems at first to be rather simple, a mere decoration for a lot of music video style dances and songs.  Karan (Akshaye Khanna) is a handsome choreographer and lead dancer of a dance troupe trying to audition for a job on a multi-million dollar luxury cruise ship.  His partner (and lover) is the very beautiful Priya (Amisha Patel) and they sing and dance up a storm.  The ship's owner is the billionaire Raj (Bobby Deol) and when he gives the job to the dance troupe of the rival Fernandez without a fair audition, Karan sneaks into Raj's office to convince him to audition his troupe.  Priya visits Raj's office and Raj is immediately taken with her.  Karan visits Fernandez and in the confrontation Fernandez falls to his death.  Karan connives with Priya to marry Raj then divorce him so that they will benefit from a huge alimony and be the wealthy people they so envy from their working caste state.

The cruise begins and gradually Raj and Priya sing and dance into finding love, the dance troupe is a big success, and at various ports Raj teleconferences with his grandmother (Suhasini Mulay) about his new love and wedding plans are made.  Priya accepts Raj's proposal on the condition that she remain chaste for the first month of the marriage to prove she is not a gold digger (!).  The marriage takes place (again with much colorful song and dance) and Priya is at last a grand lady in a mega mansion.

Karan is caught up in is web of deceit and when Priya discovers the true character of Karan and the extreme opposite of Karan's evil in Raj, she pledges to honor her marriage and not go through with Karan's vile plan.  What happens in the last hour or so with this love triangle is nail-chompingly tense: even the martial arts routines are employed as well as pure Hitchcock melodrama mystery thriller twists and turns.  The ending is a series of surprises.  What started out to be a jocular and wonderfully silly song and dance extravaganza ends up as a quite good melodrama.

Bollywood movies are an acquired taste.  But with actors (performers) as fine as these and with the knowledge that the film is a wonderfully honest parody, HUMRAAZ is a great one for an introduction! In Hindi and English, with English subtitles.  Grady Harp, April 05
